a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 81"
shows  "\<exists> P Q. dist P Q = 20 \<and> is_tangent P C1 \<and> is_tangent Q C2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 81"
shows  "\<exists> P Q. dist P Q = 20 \<and> is_tangent P C1 \<and> is_tangent Q C2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find two points P and Q such that the distance between them is 20 units. The point P is on a circle centered at (10, 0) with a radius of 6 units, and Q is on a circle centered at (-15, 0) with a radius of 9 units.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y P Q :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h2 : "C1 P = 36"
and h3 : "C2 Q = 81"
shows  "abs (P - Q) = 20"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y P Q :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h2 : "C1 P = 36"
and h3 : "C2 Q = 81"
shows  "abs (P - Q) = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two circles centered at (10, 0) and (-15, 0), find the distance between point P on the first circle with radius $\sqrt{36}$ and point Q on the second circle with radius $\sqrt{81}$. The final answer is 20.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 81"
and h2 : "is_tangent P C1"
and h3 : "is_tangent Q C2"
and h4 : "PQ = dist P Q"
shows  "PQ = 20"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 81"
and h2 : "is_tangent P C1"
and h3 : "is_tangent Q C2"
and h4 : "PQ = dist P Q"
shows  "PQ = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider two circles C1 and C2 with equations $(x - 10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x + 15)^2 + y^2 = 81$, respectively. Let P be a point on C1 and Q be a point on C2 such that P and Q are tangent to their respective circles. If PQ denotes the distance between P and Q, find PQ. The final answer is 20.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 - 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 - 81"
and h2 : "\<exists> P Q. dist P Q = 20 \<and> is_tangent P C1 \<and> is_tangent Q C2"
shows  "20 = (THE d. \<exists> P Q. dist P Q = d \<and> is_tangent P C1 \<and> is_tangent Q C2)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 - 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 - 81"
and h2 : "\<exists> P Q. dist P Q = 20 \<and> is_tangent P C1 \<and> is_tangent Q C2"
shows  "20 = (THE d. \<exists> P Q. dist P Q = d \<and> is_tangent P C1 \<and> is_tangent Q C2)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the distance between the points where two circles tangent. The equation of the first circle is $(x - 10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and for the second circle is $(x + 15)^2 + y^2 = 81$. The answer is 20 units.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h2 : "C1 x y = 36"
and h3 : "C2 x y = 81"
and h4 : "\<forall> P Q. dist P Q = sqrt ((fst Q - fst P) powr 2 + (snd Q - snd P) powr 2)"
and h5 : "\<forall> P Q. is_tangent P Q C1 C2"
shows  "shortest_distance C1 C2 = 20"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem 
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h2 : "C1 x y = 36"
and h3 : "C2 x y = 81"
and h4 : "\<forall> P Q. dist P Q = sqrt ((fst Q - fst P) powr 2 + (snd Q - snd P) powr 2)"
and h5 : "\<forall> P Q. is_tangent P Q C1 C2"
shows  "shortest_distance C1 C2 = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider two circles on a plane, Circle 1 and Circle 2. Circle 1 is centered at (10, 0) with a radius of 6 units, and Circle 2 is centered at (-15, 0) with a radius of 9 units. If a tangent line is drawn from any point P on Circle 1 to any point Q on Circle 2, what is the shortest possible distance between Circle 1 and Circle 2 along this tangent line? The answer is 20 units.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 - 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 - 81"
and h2 : "\<exists> P Q. distance P Q = 20 \<and> tangent_to C1 P \<and> tangent_to C2 Q"
shows  "distance P Q = 20"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 - 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 - 81"
and h2 : "\<exists> P Q. distance P Q = 20 \<and> tangent_to C1 P \<and> tangent_to C2 Q"
shows  "distance P Q = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the distance between two points P and Q, where P is a point of tangency to the circle described by the equation $(x - 10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and Q is a point of tangency to the circle described by the equation $(x + 15)^2 + y^2 = 81$. The final answer is $20$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h2 : "C1 x y = 36"
and h3 : "C2 x y = 81"
and h4 : "\<exists>P Q. P \<in> C1 \<and> Q \<in> C2 \<and> is_tangent C1 P \<and> is_tangent C2 Q \<and> dist P Q = a"
shows  "a = 20"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h2 : "C1 x y = 36"
and h3 : "C2 x y = 81"
and h4 : "\<exists>P Q. P \<in> C1 \<and> Q \<in> C2 \<and> is_tangent C1 P \<and> is_tangent C2 Q \<and> dist P Q = a"
shows  "a = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider two circles in the plane, Circle1 and Circle2. Circle1 has a center at (10, 0) and a radius of 6. Circle2 has a center at (-15, 0) and a radius of 9. Find the distance 'a' between a point P on the circle1 and a point Q on the circle2 such that the lines drawn from the centers of the circles to P and Q respectively are tangent to the circles. The final answer is 20.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 81"
and h2 : "C1 = (\<lambda> x y. (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2)"
and h3 : "C2 = (\<lambda> x y. (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2)"
and h4 : "\<exists> P Q. P \<in> C1 \<and> Q \<in> C2 \<and> is_tangent P Q C1 C2"
shows  "distance P Q = 20"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 81"
and h2 : "C1 = (\<lambda> x y. (x - 10) powr 2 + y powr 2)"
and h3 : "C2 = (\<lambda> x y. (x + 15) powr 2 + y powr 2)"
and h4 : "\<exists> P Q. P \<in> C1 \<and> Q \<in> C2 \<and> is_tangent P Q C1 C2"
shows  "distance P Q = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider two circles in the plane. The first circle has center at (10, 0) and a radius of 6. The second circle has center at (-15, 0) and a radius of 9. The distance between a point on the first circle and a point on the second circle, such that the line segment connecting these two points is tangent to both circles, is 20.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = ((x-10) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 36)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = ((x+15) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 81)"
and h2 : "\<exists> P Q. P \<in> C1 \<and> Q \<in> C2 \<and> (\<forall> R. R \<in> C1 \<and> R \<in> C2 \<longrightarrow> dist P Q \<le> dist R Q)"
shows  "dist P Q = 20"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x y = ((x-10) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 36)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x y = ((x+15) powr 2 + y powr 2 = 81)"
and h2 : "\<exists> P Q. P \<in> C1 \<and> Q \<in> C2 \<and> (\<forall> R. R \<in> C1 \<and> R \<in> C2 \<longrightarrow> dist P Q \<le> dist R Q)"
shows  "dist P Q = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given two circles C1 and C2 where C1 is centered at (10, 0) with a radius of 6 units, and C2 is centered at (-15, 0) with a radius of 9 units, find the minimum possible distance between a point on C1 and a point on C2. The final answer is 20 units.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x = (x-10) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x = (x+15) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h2 : "C1 x = 36"
and h3 : "C2 x = 81"
and h4 : "is_tangent C1 x P"
and h5 : "is_tangent C2 x Q"
shows  "distance P Q = 20"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Circle $C_1$ has center $(10,0)$ and radius 6.
 Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.
 Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));
 R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));
 dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
 We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and C1 C2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. C1 x = (x-10) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. C2 x = (x+15) powr 2 + y powr 2"
and h2 : "C1 x = 36"
and h3 : "C2 x = 81"
and h4 : "is_tangent C1 x P"
and h5 : "is_tangent C2 x Q"
shows  "distance P Q = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given two circles $C1$ and $C2$ with equations $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$, respectively. If $P$ is a point on the tangent to $C1$ and $Q$ is a point on the tangent to $C2$, what is the distance between $P$ and $Q$? The final answer is $20$.

natural problem: Let $C_1$ and $C_2$ be circles defined by $(x-10)^2 + y^2 = 36$ and $(x+15)^2 + y^2 = 81$ respectively. What is the length of the shortest line segment $PQ$ that is tangent to $C_1$ at $P$ and to $C_2$ at $Q$?
natural solution: Let $A = (10,0).$  Circle $C_2$ has center $(-15,0)$ and radius 9.

Let $B = (-15,0).$ [asy] unitsize(0.2 cm); pair A, B, D, P, Q, R; A = (10,0); B = (-15,0); D = (0,0); P = intersectionpoint(Circle(A,6),arc((A + D)/2, abs(A - D)/2, 180, 360)); Q = intersectionpoint(Circle(B,9),arc((B + D)/2, abs(B - D)/2, 0, 180));

R = extension(B,Q,A,A + P - Q); draw(Circle(A,6)); draw(Circle(B,9)); draw(P--Q); draw((-26,0)--(18,0)); draw(B--R--A); draw(A--P); draw(rightanglemark(B,Q,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(A,P,D,40)); draw(rightanglemark(B,R,A,40));

dot("$A$", A, NE); dot("$B$", B, S); label("$D$", D, SW); dot("$P$", P, SW); dot("$Q$", Q, N); label("$R$", R, N); [/asy] The shortest such segment $\overline{PQ}$ will be an internal common tangent of the two cirlces, and $\angle BQD = \angle APD = 90^\circ.$  Extend $\overline{BQ}$ past $Q$ to $R$ so that $QR = PA.$  Then $APQR$ is a rectangle.
We have that $BR = BQ + QR = BQ + PA = 9 + 6 = 15$ and $AB = 25.$  Then by Pythagoras on right triangle $ARB,$ \[AR = \sqrt{AB^2 - BR^2} = \sqrt{25^2 - 15^2} = 20.\]Therefore, $PQ = AR = \boxed{20}.$
